summary: Email chain between U.S. Department of State Diplomatic Security Service and the U.S. Attorney's Office regarding Jeffrey Epstein's passport. The State Department's Consular Affairs Bureau is seeking a court order from Epstein's upcoming bail hearing to revoke his valid passport, and the prosecution team is asked to coordinate.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Subject of the email chain; his passport is being considered for revocation by the State Department's Consular Affairs Bureau ahead of his bail hearing.

persons.name: ASAC
persons.context: An ASAC at the DSS NY Field Office is mentioned as a contact for the prosecution team to coordinate with regarding Epstein's passport.

persons.name: Special Agent
persons.context: A Special Agent from the U.S. Attorney's Office Southern District of New York initiates the email chain, cc'ing the prosecution team and introducing the ASAC.

connections.description: The ASAC is involved in the State Department's inquiry regarding revoking Epstein's passport as part of the legal proceedings against him.
The Special Agent introduces the ASAC as their former boss and a point of contact for the prosecution team regarding Epstein's passport issue.
The Special Agent is part of the prosecution team for the Epstein case and is facilitating communication about his passport.

events.title: Epstein Bail Hearing
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein is scheduled to have a bail hearing on Monday, July 15, 2019. The State Department seeks the resulting court order to revoke his passport.

locations: U.S. Department of State Diplomatic Security Service New York Field Office
U.S. Attorney's Office Southern District of New York, 1 St. Andrew's Plaza, New York, NY 10007
keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein possessed a valid passport at the time of this correspondence in July 2019.
The U.S. State Department's Consular Affairs Bureau was actively seeking to revoke Epstein's passport and requested the court order from his upcoming bail hearing to proceed.
The email chain shows coordination between the U.S. Attorney's Office prosecution team and the Diplomatic Security Service regarding Epstein's travel documents.
The prosecution team explicitly stated they had no position or directive regarding Epstein's passport, deferring to the State Department's process.
